prompt.p: You see a 35-year-old man in clinic who presents with new onset polydipsia and polyuria. He tells you he drinks at least 2 litres of water a day and feels irritable and thirsty if he does not. He is well, although you note he had meningitis last year and was involved in a car crash 3 months ago, sustaining a fractured skull. You note a recent sodium level of 150 mmol/l (normal range 135–145 mmol/l); potassium is normal at 3.8 mmol/l (normal range 3.3–4.7 mmol/l). You decide to perform a random urine and serum osmolality, as he tells you the colour of his urine is always very pale. The results obtained are:

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)

modalFeedback.p: Option D is Correct. Causes of cranial diabetes insipidus include meningitis and head injury. Diabetes insipidus is due to impaired water resorption by the kidney because of reduced ADH secretion from the posterior pituitary.
Option A is Incorrect. This causes hyponatraemic hypovolaemia, with postural hypotension and pigmentation. In addition, potassium here is normal.

Option B is Incorrect. Conn's Syndrome leads to primary hyperaldosteronism causing increased salt and water retention and decreased renin release. This would cause a low potassium level, and does not explain the polydipsia.
Option C is Incorrect. Cushing's syndrome leads to excessive mineralocorticoid release. However, this patient does not present with classic signs or symptoms of Cushing's syndrome.
Option E is Incorrect. This leads to increased ADH secretion from the pituitary gland, which leads to hyponatraemia and water retention.
